title: 100 People
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100 people are standing in a circle, and the first person has a knife in his hand. He kills the next person and passes over the knife to the 3 rd person who does the same. If this chain goes on and on, who is the last man standing?"}]}]}

title: 100 Roots
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let the 100 roots of the equation "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^{100}-5x+2=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r_{1}, r_{2}, r_{3},\\ldots, r_{100}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Find       "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" r_{1}^{100}+r_{2}^{100}+r_{3}^{100}+\\cdots+r_{100}^{100} . "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p(x) = x^{100} - 5x +2\\ 
p(x) = 0, \text{ for } x = r_1, r_2, \ldots r_{100} \\ 
p(r_1) = 0 \\ 
r_1^{100} - 5r_1 + 2 = 0 \\ 
\implies r_1^{100} = 5r_1 - 2 \\ 
p(r_n) = 0 \\ 
r_n^{100}-5r_n+2 = 0 \\ 
r_n^{100} = 5r_n - 2 \\ 
\text{Sum of }r_1^{100} + r_2^{100} + \ldots + r_{100}^{100} \\ 
= \underbrace{5r_1 - 2 + 5r_2 - 2 + \ldots + 5r_{100} - 2}_{\text{100 terms}} \\
= \underbrace{5r_1 + 5r_2 + \ldots + 5r_{100}}_{\text{100 times}} + \underbrace{-2 -2 -2 -\ldots -2}_{\text{100 times}} \\ 
= 5(r_1 + r_2 + r_3  + \ldots r_{100}) + 100 \times (-2) \\ 
= 5(0) - 200 ~~ \boxed{\text{Using Vieta's formula sum of zeros of a polynomial = } \dfrac{-b}{a} \text{, here b=0, so sum of zeros is 0}} \\ 
\boxed{= -200}
"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

P_{100} is what we want to find. We use Newton's Sums for the roots:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P_{100}=S_{1}P_{99}-S_{2}P_{98}+S_{3}P_{97}-S_{4}P_{96}+\cdots-S_{98}P_{2}+S_{99}P_{1}-100S_{100}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".
From Viete's Formula we know 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P_{1}=S_{1}=S_{2}=S_{3}=\cdots=S_{97}=S_{98}=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_{99}=5, S_{100}=2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
Substituting the values, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P_{100}=-100S_{100}=-200"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

Is it possibe, that the sum of the 100 numbers in any row, column or diagonal is different?"}]}]}

title: 100 showers
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In front of a swimming pool there are 100 showers.
But the plumber did something wrong. When you turn on your shower then you activate "},{"type":"text","text":"exactly","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" 5 other showers as well."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"blockquote","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
  "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"It is "},{"type":"text","text":"always","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" possible to choose 10 showers and close the other 90, so that the customers don't notice the defect."}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

title: 100 Singapore Dollars

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x,y,z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the number of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1,2,5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" dollar notes respectively. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+2y+5z=100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" should lie between "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"20"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", inclusive. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x,y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must be non-negative. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Notice that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = 100 - 5z - 2y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is uniquely determined for each valid pair "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(y,z)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" satisfying "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2y+5z \le 100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", or equivalently "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y \le 50-\frac{5z}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is even, let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z=2t"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0 \le t \le 10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". By substitution, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y \le 50-5t"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". so there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(50-5t+1)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" possible "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"'s. If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is odd, let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z=2t+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0 \le t \le 9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Substituting yields "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y \le 47\frac12-5t"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Hence, for every odd "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(47-5t+1)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" possible "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"'s. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The total number of ways is:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \displaystyle \sum_{t=0}^{10} (51-5t) +  \sum_{t=0}^9 (48-5t) = (11+ \sum_{t=0}^{10} (50-5t))+(-20+ \sum_{t=0}^9 (50-5t))"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=-9+2\displaystyle \sum_{t=0}^9 (50-5t)=-9+10\displaystyle \sum_{t=0}^9 (10-t)=541"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The problem is equivalent to finding how many ordered triples of non-negative integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x, y, z)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" satisfy "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+2y+5z=100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". This can be further simplified to finding the number of ordered triples of non-negative integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x, y)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2x+5y\leq100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", since the number of one dollar notes can make up for the remainder."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, we are trying to find the number of lattice points on the graph of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2x+5y\leq100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x, y \geq 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which is a right triangle with 2 legs on the x and y axes. Pick's theorem states that the area of a polygon is equal to the number of lattice points in the interior of the polygon plus half the number of lattice points on the perimeter of the polygon minus one: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A = i+\frac{e}{2}-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus, it suffices to find the area of the triangle and the number of lattice points the triangle's perimeter passes through and then use Pick's theorem to find the number of interior lattice points and then the total number of lattice points."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"On the hypotenuse of the right triangle, we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2x=5(20-y)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so x must be a multiple of 5. We get 9 lattice points: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(5, 18), (10, 16), \cdots (45, 2)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". On the vertical leg of the right triangle excluding the origin, we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = 0, 0<y \leq 20"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" which yields 20 points. On the horizontal leg, we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y = 0, 0<x \leq 50"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", yielding 50 points. Finally, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(0, 0)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is our last point. The right triangle passes through a total of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1+9+20+50=80"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" lattice points. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The area of our right triangle is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{1}{2}\times 20\times 50=500"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so by Pick's theorem, we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i = 500-\frac{80}{2}+1 = 461"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" lattice points in the interior of the triangle, and we have 80 lattice points on the perimeter of the triangle, so in total, we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"461+80=\boxed{541}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" lattice points, the number of ways we can make $100."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x, y, z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the number of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\$5, \$2, \$1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" notes respectively. Then the problem is equivalent to the number of non-negative solutions to the equation "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5x+2y+z = 100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Next note that for any values of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", there is only one solution for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", therefore the number of solution is equivalent to the number of non-negative solutions for the inequality "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5x+2y\leq 100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now consider the case where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=2k, 0\leq k\leq 10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". The number of solutions for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lfloor\frac{100-10k}{2}\rfloor+1=51-5k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Total number of solutions for this case is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum_{k=0}^{10} 51-5k = 286"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For the case "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=2k+1, 0\leq k\leq 9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the number of solutions for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lfloor\frac{100-10k-5}{2}\rfloor+1=48-5k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Total number of solutions for this case is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum_{k=0}^9 48-5k = 255"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" So total number of solutions is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"286+255=\mbox{541}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let a,b,c denote the number of $1,$2,$5 notes that are used, respectively."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We must find the number of nonnegative integer triplets (a,b,c) such that
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+2b+5c = 100"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This is equivalent to find the number of nonnegative integer pairs (b,c) such that 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2b+5c \leq 100"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
since the rest ("},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100-2b-5c \geq 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":") can be covered with the $1 notes."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Given "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the possible "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" values are from "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \lfloor \frac{100-5c}{2} \rfloor "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and it's easy to see that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c \leq 100/5 = 20"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence the number of possible pairs are
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \sum_{c=0}^{20}  1+\lfloor \frac{100-5c}{2} \rfloor  "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Either calculate manually for each "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", or divide the sum for odd/even "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and the  terms can be expressed without floor"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Odd "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" : "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1+\lfloor \frac{100-5c}{2} \rfloor = 50 - \frac{5c-1}{2} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Even "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" : "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1+\lfloor \frac{100-5c}{2} \rfloor = 51 - \frac{5}{2} c "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"and it becomes
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(3+8+\cdots + 48) + (1+6+\cdots+51)"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= \frac{(3+48)*10}{2} + \frac{(1+51)*11}{2} = 255+286 = 541"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We can have any number of $5 notes between 0 and 20. If we have n $5 notes, we must have $100-5n left to make out of $2 and $1 notes. We can then have any whole number of $2 notes (call the number of $2 notes m) between 0 and (100-5n)/2, because if the total is under $100, we can simply fill the remainder with $1 notes (for example, if we had 13 $5 notes, there would be $35 remaining, so we could have any one of 0, 1, 2, 3,...,17  $2 notes, and however many $1 notes necessary to total $100). For even values of n, we have n: 0, 2,...,20; the corresponding values for m are: 51, 46,..., 1
For odd n, we have n: 1, 3,...,19
m: 48, 43,...3
These possibilities for m form two arithmetic series, the sum of the first one is 286, the sum of the second one is 255.
255+286=541, which is the answer."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x,y,z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the number of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1,2,5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" dollar notes respectively. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+2y+5z=100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" should lie between "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"20"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", inclusive. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x,y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must be non-negative. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Notice that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = 100 - 5z - 2y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is uniquely determined for each valid pair "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(y,z)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" satisfying "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2y+5z \le 100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", or equivalently "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y \le 50-\frac{5z}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is even, let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z=2t"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0 \le t \le 10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". By substitution, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y \le 50-5t"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". so there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(50-5t+1)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" possible "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"'s. If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is odd, let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z=2t+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0 \le t \le 9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Substituting yields "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y \le 47\frac12-5t"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Hence, for every odd "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(47-5t+1)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" possible "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"'s. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The total number of ways is:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \displaystyle \sum_{t=0}^{10} (51-5t) +  \sum_{t=0}^9 (48-5t) = (11+ \sum_{t=0}^{10} (50-5t))+(-20+ \sum_{t=0}^9 (50-5t))"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=-9+2\displaystyle \sum_{t=0}^9 (50-5t)=-9+10\displaystyle \sum_{t=0}^9 (10-t)=541"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let the number of 1$,2$ and 5$ notes be x,y and z respectively. Let's assume there are no 5$ notes.So,the 100$ contains only combinations of 1$ and 2$ i.e x+2y=100. We have 51 solutions for this. Similarly, when we take only 2$ and 5$ into accoutn we have 2y+5z=100. We have 11 solutions and for x+5z=100 we have 21 solutions. But, we have included 3 solutions twice i.e when (100,0,0), (0,50,0) and (0,0,20). Therefore total solutions as of now is 80."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, let z =1.Hence, x+2y=95. We have to calculate solutions for this equation keeping in mind x and y cannot be zero,since we have included the results in the above 80 solutions.For different values of z ranging from 1 to 19( it cannot be 20 or 0 because the results for them have already been includedin the above 80 solutions) we have the following:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+2y=95 gives us 47 solutions.      x+2y=90 gives us 44 solutions
x+2y=85 gives us 42 solutions        x+2y=80 gives us 39 solutions
x+2y=75 gives us 37 solutions        x+2y=70  gives us 34 solutions
:                                                       :
:                                                       :
:                                                       :
x+2y= 5 gives us 2 solutions           x+2y=10 gives us 4 solutions."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Both the series above are Arithmetic progressions with common difference of 5. The sum of 1st series is 245 and 2nd series is 216."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore,the total number of solutions are 80+245+216=541"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"First we calculate the number of possible ways if we have only 1 and 2 dollars.
Suppose we need to make "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" dollars. Then the possible number of ways is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[\frac n2]+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[n]"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the greatest integer lesser than or equal to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".[This is pretty elementary because there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[\frac n2]"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" cases where different numbers of 2 dollars are used and one case where all are 1 dollars.]
Now we have 21 cases.
CASE1:0 five dollar. There are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[\frac{100}{2}]+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" possible ways.
CASE2:1 five dollar. There are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[\frac{95}{2}]+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" possible ways. 
.
.
.
CASE21:20 five dollars. There are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[\frac 02]+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" possilbe ways.
Adding them we get 541 possible ways."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For a fixed "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we seek the number of solutions to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a + 2b = 100-5c "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". We notice that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is always even, thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100-5c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must have the same parity. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100-5c \ "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is odd then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a = 1, 3, 5, \ldots 100-5c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" gives valid solutions for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a + 2b = 100 - 5c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", thus there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{101-5c}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" pairs of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(a,b,c)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c = 1, 3, 5, \ldots, 17, 19"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". 
Hence the total number of solutions for this case are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{101}{2}\times 10 - \frac{5}{2}\times 20\times 5 = 255"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100-5c \ "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is even then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a = 0, 2, 4, 6, \ldots 100-5c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" gives valid solutions for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a + 2b = 100 - 5c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", thus there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{100-5c}{2} + 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" pairs of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(a,b,c)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c = 0, 2, 4, 6, \ldots, 18, 20"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". 
Hence the total number of solutions for this case are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{100}{2}\times 11 - \frac{5}{2}\times 22\times 5 + 11 = 286"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"255 + 286 = 541"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" possible solutions. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note: The possible solutions for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+2b=100-5c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for a fixed "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is equal to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left \lfloor \frac{100-5c}{2} \right \rfloor + 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lfloor x \rfloor"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" denotes the greatest integer smaller than or equal to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+2y+5z=100
0≤x≤100.this implies 0≤100−2y−5z≤100.this implies 0≤2y+5z≤100 .this implies0≤y≤⌊(100−5z)/2⌋
As 0≤5z≤100,0≤z≤20
If z is odd =2a+1,0≤y≤⌊(100−5(2a+1))/2⌋=47−5a,47−5a+1=48−5a values of z
So, 0≤2a+1≤20.this implies 0≤a≤9
If z is even,=2b,0≤y≤⌊(100−5(2b))/2⌋=50−5b,50−5b+1=51−5b values of z
So, 0≤2b≤20.this implies 0≤b≤10
So, the number of combinations =∑0≤a≤9(48−5a)+∑0≤b≤10(51−5b)=48⋅10+51⋅11−5∑0≤a≤9a−5∑0≤b≤10b=541"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 100 socks
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here's a pretty easy question to solve in your spare time. Let's say you have 100 colored socks and four colored bags. The socks and bags are colored in various (and different) colors: You have to match socks and bags that's in the same color. (For example, matching a red sock with a red bag is a correct pair) What's the probability that you would manage to match only 99 pairs of socks and bags correctly? "}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hint: The answer might be more "},{"type":"text","text":"simple","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" than you thought."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here's the oversimplified answer in case you want to check your answer fast: Since you matched 99 socks correctly, the other 1 pair has to be correct. So the answer is...  [Drum Roll]  0%."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"It's all pretty simple when you reduce the number of the socks. Let's say we have 3 socks and bags in red, blue and orange. If you match the blue bags with blue socks, and the red bags with red socks, there's no possibility of mismatching the rest. The result is same on a big scale, such as 150 socks or even 10,000 socks. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Conclusion: It's impossible to correctly match only "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" socks out of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" socks in this kind of situations."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            The reason I answered 0% was because the question stated you have "100 socks", so "99 pairs" would require 198 socks, making it an impossible scenario.

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            To follow on what Tristan said, you need to say "100 pairs of socks" initially.  Or by pair do you mean a pairing between sock and bag?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A more general issue is that you are presenting this as a problem of probability, but I'm not seeing any probability distribution mentioned here.  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In any case, your conclusion is flawed.  How are you defining a correct pairing?  If it's sock to bag, then it's entirely possible to misplace exactly one sock.  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I went for 0% based on the idea that the socks come in pairs and it would make no sense to put a pair of socks into two different bags. But there is a real issue with asking for a probability as a solution when no actual randomness is apparently being used.  In that context, 0% is the only possible answer, since it can also mean "impossible".  With no random distribution specified, how could one end up with 20% or 40%?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n_1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n_2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" denote the number of lines for either a row or column, respectively. Without loss of generality, let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n_1 \geq n_2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". The number of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1\times 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" squares in an "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n_1 \times n_2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" figure is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(n_1 - 1)(n_2 - 1)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". The number of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2\times2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" squares in an "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n_1 \times n_2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" figure is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(n_1 - 2)(n_2 - 2)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". This pattern repeats until the number of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n_2 -1 \times n_2 - 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" squares are counted. Therefore, the number of total squares in an "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n_1 \times n_2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" figure is
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum_{i = 1}^{n_2-1}(n_1-i)(n_2-i)"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Solving this for 100 squares leads to 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum_{i = 1}^{n_2-1}(n_1-i)(n_2-i) = 100"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum_{i = 1}^{n_2-1}n_1 n_2 - (n_1 + n_2)\sum_{i = 1}^{n_2-1}i + \sum_{i = 1}^{n_2-1}i^{2}= 100"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
 "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n_1 n_2(n_2 -1) - (n_1 + n_2)\big(\frac{(n_2-1)(n_2)}{2}\big) + \frac{(n_2 - 1)(n_2)(2n_2 -1)}{6} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" 
After much rearranging and dreaded algebra we get
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3n_1n_2^{2} - 3n_1 n_2 - n_2^{3} + n_2 = 600"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" 
After some factoring we get
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(n_2)(n_2-1)(3n_1 - (n_2+1)) = 2^{3}\times3\times5^{2}   "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" 
The two numbers that satisfy the equation and minimize the sum of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n_1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n_2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n_2 = 6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n_1 = 9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" so the answer is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"15"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                            Sure! Factoring the left-hand side as much as possible allows us to do a very efficient guess and check method on the number n1 and n2. This is because the three terms must satisfy the prime factorization on the right hand side. Also, realizing that some terms must be either even or odd (if n2 is even, n2 -1 must be odd) reduces the amount of numbers we must check. Of course, one can always solve the equation as a cubic in terms of n2, but the splitting of factors on both sides is, again, a very efficient guess and check method.

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Yeah, maximum squares (i.e. fewest lines) is given by horizontal = vertical or difference of 1. Starting from 3 lines yields 0 squares, each additional line adds squares according to the series 1,1,3,3,6,6,10,10,15,15,21,21 etc. That is, adding a line to a square matrix adds the same number of squares to the total as the previous line that formed the square, and then adding a line in the opposite direction (forming a bigger square) increases the total by the next term in the series of "sum of all numbers 1 to k". Another way to word this is noticing that each pair of consecutive numbers in that series sums to the next square.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Simple,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Start:
For n number of lines, we can form maximum number of squares of each type only if the number of horizontal lines equals the number of vertical lines, if n is an even number. Else, one side should have only one more line than the other, for n being odd. (: we don't want rectangles to occupy our space :)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Calculations: 
Let's calculate for an even n and we will arrive the number which gives 100 squares or just below 100. (let m = n / 2)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The total number of squares of length 1 will be (m-1)x(m-1), 2 will be (m-2)x(m-2) and so on till m-1 i.e. 1."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Sum: 1+2x2 + 3x3 +... + (m-1)x(m-1) = (m-1)(m)(2m-1)/6  (put m-1 in summation of squares formula)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This,  for m = 7,  gives total number of squares 91. For m = 8,  it is 140. So the number of lines can be {2x7+1, 2x8} i.e either 15 or 16. For n = 16(m=8), it is 140 - YES, it is more than 100; what about n=15?  - We only considered cases where n is even. Let's add one more line to the 7x7 figure. This line will increase the number of 1x1 squares by 6, 2x2 squares by 5, and no need to calculate further. It already more than 100 (91+6+5)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Still we don't know if n = 15 will give the exact sum 100 for some combination of horizontal (H) and vertical lines(V)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let's do that: given sum of H and V lines 15, start with a 6x6 square (total number of squares 55 with the derived equation above) and start adding lines to V side (or H, but choose same side for each addition). You will notice the sum will start increasing by 15 (i.e., 5+4+3+2+1). Adding 3 such lines will give us the total 55+15x3 i.e. 100."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We won!!! "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Answer: 15"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":":)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let suppose you want to calculate number of squares in the grid with length L (distance between two adjacent lines considered to be unity). "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The number of choices you have on the set of vertical lines will be (m - L), for first line you have Lth line, 2nd (L+1)th and so on, i. e., (m-L) number of combinations."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Similar is the case with the set of horizontal lines. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Total number of squares: (m-1)x(m-1)+(m-2)x(m-2)...+1x1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, getting back to your question:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The sum of squares of n consecutive natural number starting from 1 is:
n"},{"type":"text","text":"(n+1)","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"(2n+1)/6 - easy to proove."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Just key in n as m-1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thanks 
:)

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"On an "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m \times n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" grid, suppose without loss of generality that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m \ge n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m - n + 1 = a."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" There are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"mn"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 \times 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" squares, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(m-1)(n-1)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2\times 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" squares, and so on down to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(m-n+1)1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n \times n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" squares. Adding these in reverse, the total is
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
\begin{aligned}
1 \cdot a + 2(a+1) + 3(a+2) + \cdots + n(a+n-1) &= \frac{n(n+1)}2 a + (1 \cdot 0 + 2\cdot 1 + 3 \cdot 2 + \cdots + n(n-1)) \\
&= \frac{n(n+1)}2 a + \frac{n^3-n}3
\end{aligned}
"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
(by an easy induction, or by using the formulas for the sums of the first "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" numbers and the sums of the first "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" squares. Knowing this formula is actually not necessary for what follows.)
If this equals "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100,"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n^3-n \le 300,"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n \le 6."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" Now we can just write down the six equations and see what we get:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
\begin{aligned}
n = 1 &\Rightarrow a + 0 = 100 \Rightarrow  a = 100 \Rightarrow m=100, n = 1 \\
n = 2 &\Rightarrow 3a + 2 = 100 \Rightarrow \text{no solutions} \\
n = 3 &\Rightarrow 6a + 8 = 100 \Rightarrow \text{no solutions} \\
n = 4 &\Rightarrow 10a + 20 = 100 \Rightarrow a = 8 \Rightarrow m=11, n = 4 \\
n = 5 &\Rightarrow 15a + 40 = 100 \Rightarrow a = 4 \Rightarrow m = 8, n = 5 \\
n = 6 &\Rightarrow 21a + 70 = 100 \Rightarrow \text{no solutions}
\end{aligned}
"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
So there are three solutions, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(100,1),(11,4),(8,5)."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" The number of lines needed to draw an "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m \times n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" grid is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m+n+2,"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" so the minimum is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8+5+2=\fbox{15}."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If we build a 7x7 square it can fit 36 1x1 squares, 25 2x2 squares, 16 3x3 squares, 9 4x4 squares, 4 5x5 squares, 1 6x6 square=93 squares
The amount fo the lines to make it is 14.If we add a line it results more than 100."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Instead of counting the lines, let's start by considering "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a \times b "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" rectangle ("},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" integers), and let's assume "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a\geq b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". There will be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+b+2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" lines.
Also, there will be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ab"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1\times 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" squares, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(a-1)(b-1)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2\times 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" squares, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(a-2)(b-2)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3\times 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" squares, etc. up till "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" (1+a-b)(1) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b\times b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" squares."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, let's try some values for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Firstly, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". This results in a total of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" squares, so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a=100 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to get the correct number of squares.
For "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" b=2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we need to sum the number of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1\times 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and the number of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2\times 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" squares. I.e. there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ab+(a-1)(b-1)=2ab+1-a-b = 3a-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" squares. No matter what integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" we choose, this cannot be equal to 100 exactly.
In a similar manner, for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" b=3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" we obtain "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6a-4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" squares, so no solution, for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" b=4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" we obtain "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10a-10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" squares, i.e. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=11"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" b=5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" we obtain "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"15a-20"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" squares, i.e. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Finally, for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b=6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"21a-35"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" squares.
We don't have to investigate "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b\geq 7"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", as that would mean "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+b\geq 14"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", a bigger sum than we obtained for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b=5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So we have seen that the solution "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=8, b=5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the optimal solution, i.e. a minimum of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8+5+2=15"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" lines is needed to obtain exactly 100 squares."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If a figure has exactly a(a+b) small 1x1 squares, then there is a configuration with (a+1)+(a+b+1) lines (like the one seen above with a grid-like shape) and this is the configuration with the least lines which achieves a(a+b) little square.  We count the number of squares to be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac {2a^{3} + 3(1+b)a^{2} + (1+3b)a}{6} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".**  Direct search on a,b yields (5,3) to be the smallest solution (you know that a<7, as otherwise you're busted from the outset).  Hence the answer is 15."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"**Counting the squares: we have a perfect axa square right next to an axb rectangle.  First count the squares in perfect axa square: 1 axa square, ..., a^2 1x1 squares.  Hence, there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \sum_{k=1}^{a} k^{2} = \frac{a^{3}}{3} +\frac{a^{2}}{2} + \frac{a}{6} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" squares in the figure.  Next, we count the 'new' squares from the axb rectangle, that is, the squares which themselves contain at least one 1x1 square within the axb rectangle.  There are b such axa squares, ..., and ab such 1x1 squares.  Hence, there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b\sum_{k=1}^{a} k = b(\frac{a^{2}}{2} + \frac{a}{2}) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" new squares.  Adding these totals together, we have counted all the squares in the figure, as each tile is either in the axb rectangle or not (but not both)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: Hundredth Derivative of Sinc Function
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/solvable/ee4fcef62d.29932d9102.7z1OOg.png?width=250"}},{"type":"text","text":"
In mathematics, physics, and engineering, the cardinal sine function or "},{"type":"text","text":"sinc function","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":", denoted by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\def\sinc{\text{sinc }} \sinc x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", is defined by
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
\def\sinc{\text{sinc }}
\sinc x=\frac{\sin x}{x}.
"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
The term "sinc" is a contraction of the function's full Latin name, the "},{"type":"text","text":"sinus","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"text","text":"cardinalis","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" (cardinal sine). It was introduced by Phillip M. Woodward in his 1952 paper "Information Theory and Inverse Probability in Telecommunication" in which he said the function "occurs so often in Fourier analysis and its applications that it does seem to merit some notation of its own" and his 1953 book "Probability and Information Theory, with Applications to Radar"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Compute "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" m+n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" m"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are  "},{"type":"text","text":"relatively prime","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":", where"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
\def\sinc{\text{sinc }}
\left.\frac{d^{100}}{dx^{100}}(\sinc x)\right|_{x=0}=\frac{m}{n}.

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"this approach does not use the series expansion...."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(NOTE: yny^nyn represents 'n'th derivative of y)","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"-let "},{"type":"text","text":"y=sin(x)/x","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"then "},{"type":"text","text":"yx=sin(x)","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"after differentiating once we have"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"xy1{ y }^{ 1 }y1+y=cos(x)","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"the next derivative (2nd)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"xy2{ y }^{ 2 }y2+2y1{ y }^{ 1 }y1= -sin(x)","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"and so on......."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"we get the general form to be"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"xyny^{n}yn+nyn−1y^{n-1}yn−1=sin(x) *   (where *n=4z","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"   and n,z belong to integers) "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"hence to find the 100th derivative at '0' we need to put n=101","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
giving us"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0y101y^{101}y101+ 101y100y^{100}y100=cos(0)","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"   "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[cos(0) because 100 is of the form '4z' and 101 th is the next derivative]","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"finally 
"},{"type":"text","text":"101y100y^{100}y100=1","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"and the hundredth derivative is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1/101"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{\sin(x)}{x}= \int_{0}^{1}\cos(ux)du "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Now, using leibiniz rule repeatedly, gives , 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \left( \frac{\sin(x)}{x} \right)^{(100)}  = \int_{0}^{1} u^{100}\cos(ux) du "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Putting "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x =0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" , 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"  \left(\frac{\sin(x)}{x} \right)^{(100)} = \int_{0}^{1} u^{100} du = \frac{1}{101} \Box "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The series expansion of sinx is"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle sinx"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \sum_{n = 0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^nx^{2n+1}}{(2n+1)!}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \frac{sinx}{x} = \sum_{n = 0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^nx^{2n}}{(2n+1)!}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Then the first derivate is
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \frac{d}{dx} (\frac{sinx}{x}) = \sum_{n = 1}^\infty \frac{(-1)^nx^{2n-1}}{(2n+1)(2n-1)!}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So is easy to see that"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \frac{d^{100}}{dx^{100}} (\frac{sinx}{x}) = \sum_{n = 50}^\infty \frac{(-1)^nx^{2n-100}}{(2n+1)(2n-100)!}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note that the sum starts with n = 50, this is because in each derivate a term (2n - a) appears and if n = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{a}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and n is a integer this term is zero. So the sum need to start with n > "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{a}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and since the last a that appears is a = 99, n needs to be iqual to 50."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If x = 0 the only term that is not zero is for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", i.e., when n = 50:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \frac{d^{100}}{dx^{100}}(\frac{sinx}{x}) = \frac{1}{2 \times 50 + 1} = \frac {1}{101}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Which means that m = 1, n = 101 and m + n = 102."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
